awd_titl_txt: RUI: Role of Germ Cell Nanoparticles during Germline Specification in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the biological functions and assembly of germ cell nanoparticles. These are small molecular structures that may hold a key to unexplained fundamental aspect of germline, namely its unique ability to give rise to the next-generation individuals and therefore, ensure the continuity of life. Germ cells belong to a special class of cells that produce egg and sperm which unite to generate a completely new organism. Germ cell nanoparticles have been remarkably conserved across animal phyla indicating their crucial biological importance. In addition, this research may promote design of artificial nanoparticles with desired molecular characteristics thereby leading to technological breakthroughs. This project will involve undergraduate, graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar and will provide opportunities for training of future active participants in science and education fields. In addition, the research topics will be incorporated into genetics courses and a new cell biology laboratory module will be designed. This research will be described on the University National Public Radio providing a great platform to reach out to the general public.

This project aims to understand the principles of the functional assembly of germ cell molecular complexes composed of RNA and proteins required for germline development in diverse organisms. Components of these complexes include Tudor domain-containing proteins, Piwi proteins, small Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) and enzymes of the glycolytic cluster. These complexes play a major role in the silencing of transposable elements, which otherwise might lead to harmful mutations. However, the mechanisms controlling their assembly remains a mystery. To address this gap, a combination of approaches--including genetics, biochemistry, as well as in vitro and in vivo experiments--will be used to test the roles of the component proteins in assembly of these germ cell particles in Drosophila.  Because these structures have been evolutionarily conserved, this research can serve as a paradigm for studying other large and dynamic ribonucleoprotein granules.  Moreover, the results have the potential to reveal new insights into how such nanoparticles function to preserve the integrity of the next generation genetic material.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided new significant insights into the functional assembly of distinct molecular complexes/nanoparticles assembled in large granules of germ cells in many animals (germ granules). Germ cells give rise to egg and sperm, therefore, these cells are responsible for life continuity. Being landmark structures in germ cells of many organisms, germ granules are likely to function as crucial molecular regulators and determinants of germ cell fate. As the result of this research, several fundamental principles of the germ granule assembly were uncovered. First, it was demonstrated that these granules can form from distinct protein clusters, partially associating at interaction hubs, similarly to the construction of a structure from LEGO pieces or creating a mosaic art. Interestingly, it was found that similar germ cell-like granules are assembled in glial cells of the adult brain and they are also assembled from distinct protein clusters demonstrating that the assembly of these granules follows the same principles in different cell types. In addition, it was found that at the interaction hubs, protein granule components are assembled on a large molecular scaffold Tudor protein, which contains 11 interaction modules referred to as Tudor domains. Furthermore, it was shown that during the assembly of germ granules, Tudor utilizes different strategies to recruit granule components, including engagement of either specific single Tudor domains or, alternatively, distinct tandem Tudor domains, in binding to different Tudor partners. This broad binding repertoire of Tudor scaffold molecule and novel germ cell-like granules discovered in this work, suggest that the same protein scaffold is used to assemble subcellular structures in different cells which may be tuned or repurposed to play different roles determined by different Tudor partners in these cells. Therefore, the outcomes of this research are likely to have general significance for cell biology and understanding the subcellular organization.  

The project provided exciting research opportunities for several undergraduate, graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar, who, after grant tenure, all have continued their professional activities and chose careers in STEM or health-related fields. Furthermore, the original research has been effectively incorporated into several undergraduate courses including genetics and cell biology, thereby enhancing student learning by raising student interest in cutting-edge research and by directly conveying the excitement of scientific discovery.
